Gabriel García Márquez. Born on March 6, 1927, in Aracataca, Colombia, was one of the most significant authors of the 20th century.

Affectionately known as “Gabo” in Latin America, he was a key figure in the literary movement known as Magical Realism, which blends magical elements with realistic situations.

García Márquez’s upbringing in the tropical region of Colombia with his maternal grandparents profoundly influenced his writing, infusing it with a blend of supernatural and ordinary, a characteristic feature of Magical Realism.

He began his career as a journalist while studying law, but soon turned to fiction.

His most famous novel, “One Hundred Years of Solitude” (1967), is considered a masterpiece and a defining work of Magical Realism.

It tells the multi-generational story of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo, drawing on elements from Colombian history and culture.

This novel brought him international fame and is often cited as one of the greatest works of fiction of the 20th century.

Other significant works include “Love in the Time of Cholera” (1985) and “The Autumn of the Patriarch” (1975).

His literary prowess extended beyond novels to short stories and journalistic pieces.
